title: How to Dye Your Hair Mauve

steps.headline: Determine if your hair needs bleaching and toning.
steps.description: Hair dye is translucent, so it adds to the color that is already there. If you were to dye brown hair mauve, you will end up with a very dark mauve instead. For the most accurate and vibrant color, you should start with pale blond hair. If you have blond hair, tone it first to bring it up to a pale, platinum color. Putting mauve dye on top of yellow hair would turn it orange-gold. If you want a dark mauve color and you have brown hair, dye a test strand and see if you are happy with the result. If you have dark brown or black hair, you will need to bleach and tone your hair in order to get the dye to show up.

steps.headline: Start off with dry, healthy hair.
steps.description: Bleach is very harsh, but you can reduce the damage by taking the right, preparatory steps. Use a deep conditioning mask for two weeks before you bleach it. It would be an even better idea to not wash your hair for a few days before the process. The natural oils produced by your scalp will protect your hair further. Make sure that your hair is dry. Never apply bleach to wet hair.

steps.headline: Section off your hair into four quadrants.
steps.description: Part your hair down the middle, from hairline to nape. Brush each section over each shoulder, then part it again horizontally, going from ear-to ear. Twist each section into a bun and secure it with a clip.

steps.headline: Protect your skin and clothing.
steps.description: Put on an old shirt you don't care about, or drape an old towel/dyeing cape around your shoulders. Apply some petroleum jelly around your hairline, ears, and back of neck. Finally, pull on a pair of plastic gloves. It would be a good idea to cover your work surface with newspaper or a plastic bag.

steps.headline: Prepare your bleach using a volume that is suitable for your hair.
steps.description: In general, the darker your hair is, the higher volume developer you should use. A 10 volume would be suitable for blonds and light browns, while a 20 volume would be best for medium browns. If you have very dark hair, stick with a 30 volume developer. Prepare the bleach in a non-metal bowl. Use a plastic spoon or a tinting brush to mix it.

steps.headline: Consider balayage if you have brown hair and want chocolate mauve.
steps.description: Bleaching hair can be damaging, especially if you have dark hair. If your hair is a medium shade of brown, consider dyeing your hair using the balayage technique instead. This way, you will only need to dye the tips. This will give you the color known as "chocolate mauve." Try to get the bleached parts to a level 10, if possible. Once you complete the balayage, click here to continue.

steps.headline: Apply the bleach to your hair, one quadrant at a time, starting from the ends.
steps.description: Un-clip one of the back quadrants. Use a tinting brush to apply the bleach in thin layers, starting from the ends and working your way to the roots. Move onto the next back quadrant, then do the top ones. Never apply bleach to the roots first. For each quadrant: use the handle of the tinting brush to lift away thin layers of hair. Apply the bleach to these layers, starting from the uppermost one.

steps.headline: Cover your head with a plastic shower cap.
steps.description: You don't really have to do this, but it will trap the heat and allow the bleach to process faster. It would be even better to use a clear shower cap. This way, you can keep track of the bleaching process without having to peek under the cap.

steps.headline: Allow the bleach to process for the time recommended on the packaging.
steps.description: Do not leave the bleach on your head for longer than the time recommended on the package. In most cases, this will be 30 to 45 minutes. If you have dark hair and want to go really light, you'll need to do a second bleaching process. Check your hair every 5 to 10 minutes or so. The processing speed will depend on your hair, as well as what level of developer you used. The higher the developer, the faster the processing. You want your hair to bleach to yellow (or orange for dark hair).

steps.headline: Wash your hair with cool water and shampoo.
steps.description: Once your hair has reached the level of lightness desired, remove the shower cap and rinse the bleach out. Follow up with a shampoo meant for color-treated hair. You haven't dyed your hair yet, but it will be a lot gentler on your hair than others.

steps.headline: Tone your hair with purple shampoo, if necessary.
steps.description: Bleaching often results in brassy hair. Because mauve is a cool shade, you will need to get rid of any orange tints first. Buy a bottle of purple shampoo from a beauty supply store, and wash your hair with it according to the directions on the bottle. If you can't find any purple shampoo, you can mix your own using white conditioner and purple hair dye. You need a light purple color. If you are happy with the color, you can move straight onto dyeing. It would be better if you wait a day, however, to give your hair a break.

steps.headline: Repeat the bleaching process the following week, if necessary.
steps.description: Take a look at your hair and decide if you are happy with the tone. Your hair will be the same tone, but mauve. If it is too dark for you, and you want a pastel mauve instead, wait at least one full day, then bleach again. It would be even better if you deep conditioned it between the two sessions. Keep in mind that if you have very dark hair, you may not be able to lighten it to get a pastel mauve color. You may have to settle for a medium or dark mauve. Do not do a second bleaching process if your hair feels dry or brittle. Doing a second process will damage it even more.

steps.headline: Split your hair into four sections.
steps.description: Create a center part, starting at your forehead and ending at your nape. Create a second, horizontal part going from ear-to-ear. Twist each section into a mini bun and secure it with a clip.

steps.headline: Protect your skin, clothing, and work surface.
steps.description: Cover your counter with newspaper or a plastic bag. Wrap a dyeing cape or an old towel around your shoulders. You can also put on an old shirt instead. Apply petroleum jelly to your hairline, ears, and back of neck. Finally, pull on a pair of plastic gloves.

steps.headline: Mix some mauve dye into white, silicone-free conditioner.
steps.description: Pour enough white conditioner into a non-metal mixing bowl to saturate your hair. Stir in enough gel-based mauve hair dye until you get the shade you want. If you cannot find mauve hair dye, you will have to mix a combination of colors to get a dusty pinkish-purple color. Use a gel-based punk dye, such as "Manic Panic." Play around with different combinations of dye, such as pink, purple, blue until you get the shade you want. If you are having trouble, ask a stylist at the salon to help you. Refer to a color wheel to get just the right shade.

steps.headline: Apply the dye to your hair starting from the roots.
steps.description: Choose one of the bottom sections to start with, and let it down. Apply the dye with your fingers or a tinting brush to a small, thin section, making sure to fully saturate the strands. Once you finish the section, you can leave it down, cover it with plastic wrap, or twist it back into the bun. For chocolate mauve, place a palette under the balayage, then apply the dye using a tinting brush. Be sure to blend some of the dye into the brown parts. If you are doing chocolate mauve, cover the hair with plastic wrap and leave it flat.

steps.headline: Let down another section of hair and continue dyeing.
steps.description: Do the second bottom quadrant first, then move onto the top two. Squeeze your hair after applying the dye to remove the excess conditioner. This will make the color more saturated and even. If you have very thick hair, or if you started with a balayage, you will need to work in thinner layers. For chocolate mauve, separate the layers with sheets of plastic wrap or aluminum foil to prevent color transfer.

parts.name: Processing, Rinsing, and Maintaining Your Hair

steps.headline: Gather your hair into a bun and allow it to process.
steps.description: How long it takes for the dye to process depends on the type of dye you are using, so refer to the label. Most dyes can be left in your hair for an hour or longer. Keep in mind that the longer you leave the dye in, the more vibrant the color will be. Consider covering your hair with a plastic shower cap. This will help keep the dye from drying out and prevent it from rubbing off an everything. If you started with a balayage, do not tuck your hair under a shower cap, or you will transfer the dye to the rest of your hair.

steps.headline: Rinse the dye out with cool water, then apply conditioner.
steps.description: Rinse your hair with cool water until the water runs clear first. Next, apply some color-safe conditioner. Let it sit in your hair for 2 to 3 minutes, then rinse it out. Do not use warm water or shampoo. Using cool water will lock in the dye and seal the hair's cuticle. You can wash your hair with lukewarm water and color-safe shampoo later on, but wait a few days before doing so.

steps.headline: Dry and style your hair as desired.
steps.description: Because of the dyeing technique you used, chocolate mauve lends itself well to curly or wavy styles. If you have straight hair, consider using a large curling iron to add gentle waves to it. If you have curly or wavy hair, allow it to dry naturally. Enhance your hair with some highlights or ombre. Tuck a bright pink flower into your hair for an added touch. If you're using a heated tool, make sure the apply a heat protectant product first.

steps.headline: Take care of your hair to keep it healthy and maintain the color.
steps.description: Wash your hair using cool to lukewarm water and a color-safe, sulfate-free shampoo and conditioner. Limit the heat styling, and allow your hair to air dry when possible. If you must heat-style, be sure to use a heat protectant.
